It is, according to Senator Abetz, tedious of the university to call for a restoration of the funding lost since his government came to office in 1996; tedious of the university to seek sufficient funding to offer adequate and contemporary courses for its students spread throughout the state; and no doubt tedious for Senator Abetz to receive adequate funding to place the 1,000 students turned away each year because there are no funded places for them. No doubt it is also tedious that Vice-Chancellor McNicol should point out that, in order to take up some of the undergraduate overdemand for places, the university has had to redirect it resources at the expense of postgraduate students.

speech.para: The Examiner editorial sums up the situation regarding funding—or more accurately the lack of funding—by the Howard-Kemp-Abetz government. It says:

quote.para: This is a chance for the Federal Government to make a difference in Tasmania. All it requires is the political leadership. Sadly, to date that has been missing.

speech.para: There was certainly nothing in last night's budget to make anyone more positive about anything changing on this front.

The university's submission to the Senate inquiry was straightforward. According to ABS Schools Australia, since 1996 Tasmania has blitzed the other states in increasing its higher education retention rates by 20 per cent. However, Commonwealth funding to the University of Tasmania has been slashed by at least six per cent, or more than $6 million, in the same period. Accordingly, the university turns away more than 1,000 eligible applicants a year who either go to the mainland universities or, even more tragically for Tasmania and the nation, do not continue with higher education. Clearly, higher retention rates will translate into increased higher education participation rates, or at least an increase in the demand. This is at the crux of the university's dilemma with the federal government. It needs adequate funding to absorb this increase. It has managed to absorb some of this increased demand by redirecting its resources away from postgraduate students and trimming some of its courses and administration costs. In fact, the redirection of postgraduate students has seen numbers drop over the past five years of inadequate coalition funding from 600 to 220. In 1999 it offered almost 350 places above its target and in 2000 it overenrolled by more than 200 EFTSU.

Professor McNicol has argued that, if the government did no more than simply correct the funding slide on a population comparison basis, the crisis could be substantially solved. Estimates are that an extra $15 million would increase the number of students at the university by 1,250. In essence, Tasmania has 2.4 per cent of the 15 to 64 age cohort used as a basis for calculating participation rates but only receives 2.29 per cent of the funded places on a national basis. If the Australian Maritime College is thrown into the equation, the funding figure drops further to 2.18 per cent.

Sadly, the hidden aspect of unmet demand is that nearly 2,500 Tasmanians study through interstate institutions each year. Only about 25 per cent of these students study at other institutions in courses or specialisations not offered by the University of Tasmania. Almost 18.7 per cent of Tasmanian home residents are studying interstate. This compares with a national average of 9.4 per cent of students studying outside their state of home residence.

The federal government's recent innovations initiatives will have quite modest benefits for the University of Tasmania. Research and development can only come on the back of a successful undergraduate sector. Sadly, this is lacking in Tasmania because of a lack of equitable, adequate funding of undergraduate places. This may be tedious to Senator Abetz, but thousands of Tasmanians and their families want him to support them, not deride them. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I too was unable to speak on the condolence motion yesterday for our departed colleague Peter Nugent, the former member for Aston, and I wish to do so now. People have spoken in the House of his attitudes, the causes that he took up and the projects that he involved himself in, but what I valued about Peter more than anything else was his character because, if one looked at the things he did here, one could see that his basic character underpinned all of the things that he took up.

speech.para: I really enjoyed his honesty, his forthrightness and his direct way of dealing with problems and people. It meant that you were never in doubt in any way of what he felt or thought. In this place people take so much trouble to hide their true feelings and to disguise what they really think, but Peter Nugent was not one of those. Peter Nugent was a person who in fact presented himself and his thoughts honestly and fairly at every opportunity. I enjoyed that openness of character of his and I enjoyed the relationship that we had with him.

I also want to pay tribute to the things that I believe are his lasting contributions. I know that the human rights issues are the ones that people have remembered in the House, but I feel that one of his main contributions was to our lasting relationship with Asia. I enjoyed the membership of the parliamentary Singapore Friendship Group, and I knew that Peter had a very extensive knowledge of Asia and was very significantly drawing bonds and links with the whole of South-East Asia. I thought that was a lasting and invaluable contribution which he had passed on to others, and it will be an ongoing process which cannot be reversed or changed, because he was right.

Another contribution was his professional knowledge of technology. This House would not be the same without Peter's contribution to the Presiding Officers' committee that dealt with the technology and the advances we are making. He was a professional in that area and had great knowledge. His contribution to each one of us in our electorate offices and here in the parliament is going to be lasting and ongoing because he brought a breath of fresh air to the way in which we view technology.

I want to pay tribute to a past friend, a friend who made a great contribution to this parliament. He was valued in the good times and the bad times. He and Carol certainly had a mixture of both, in a professional sense and in a personal sense. I want to convey my personal condolences and those of my family to Carol and indicate to her how much Peter was valued here, both for his representation of his electorate, which was fine and was the basis of much of what he undertook, and for his goodwill. I pay tribute to him for that. In particular, I valued him for his character.

talk.start.para: —Before I call the honourable member for Chisholm, I remind the House that the occupant of the chair exercises absolute discretion on the standard of dress. While, as a general rule, the chair would suggest that printed T-shirts are in the same sort of area as the string shirts that former member Mr Steedman was expelled from the House for wearing by Speaker Harry Jenkins, on this occasion I will allow her to speak.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I rise tonight to speak of an absolute tragedy in my electorate—the closure of the Arnott's biscuit factory. That is why I am wearing my T-shirt proudly this evening.

speech.para: I was present when, on 2 May, 600 workers were told that their jobs were going. I was there when 600 people were filing out of the factory saying, `Where has my job gone?' Husbands and wives were trying to work out what had happened, fathers and sons were shaking their heads in despair. They were asking why, and they were trying to work out where in the hell they were going to get another job. Six hundred full-time, part-time and casual jobs will be terminated, and many of these people will never find work again. This is despite the fact that the Victorian government offered Arnott's the opportunity to expand their operations in Victoria, despite the fact that it is an incredibly profitable operation and despite the fact that it had an unblemished industrial relations record.

In a prepared statement the company coldly explained how they had injected $100 million to upgrade their operations in Sydney, Brisbane and Adelaide. I do not begrudge jobs being created in other states, but I do begrudge them being created at the expense of 600 jobs in Burwood. They went on to explain that they had decided to close the Burwood site as it was 50 years old and in need of an upgrade. This was despite a $60 million profit Arnott's have taken out of Australia. They were not prepared to commit any of this profit back into upgrading this site. Rumours have been rife that Arnott's parent company, Campbells, are interested in selling off this invaluable land for development. In other words, it appears that Campbells are only interested in using the site as a cash cow to pursue Campbells' other interests worldwide, with no regard for the workers that in many cases have spent their lives working at Arnott's in Burwood. The site is 12 hectares of prime land in middle Melbourne and the company could reap something like $15 million from the sale, so a whole lot of faceless bureaucrats in the United States have determined that 600 workers are going to go at Arnott's in Burwood.

One of the more spurious claims about the closure is that the local residents were unhappy with the location of the factory. I lived within two streets of the factory for the majority of my life and I have never heard a complaint from anybody. In my years in the office as the member for Chisholm I have never had a complaint from anybody. Going back through council records, there was a complaint about the factory 15 years ago. So that rumour is absolutely spurious. My mother is still in our family home, two streets from the factory, and she has been around asking who is complaining about this site. Indeed, the factory was there before the houses were built.

Who is going to complain about living next door to a biscuit factory? There are not too many noises. Actually, there is a delightful smell. You can walk out of your house in the morning and smell biscuits being baked. Long-term residents could even tell which biscuits were coming out of the production line—whether they were Teddy Bears, Scotch Fingers or Jam Fancies. The only downside was that occasionally the dry biscuits did smell bad. But this is a factory that is not impinging on the local area. Most local residents are outraged that Arnott's are leaving, taking away jobs from the community. They are taking away an icon. They are also taking away a pride of place. Prior to becoming an Arnott's factory it was Brockhoff's, and Brockhoff's was a great contributor to the local area. People have worried about the loss of the Brockhoff Foundation support in the area as well. We will lose part of our local history when this factory closes.

At a rally held last Sunday to continue the fight to keep jobs in Burwood, one of the most moving speeches came from one of the workers. He talked about Arnott's and his life there. He started at 15. His father said, `You'll have a job for life.' Well, 20 years later he does not. His father worked at this factory. His mother worked at the factory. His brother-in-law worked at the factory. He met his wife at the factory. He talked about how he had seen the demise of quality over time because of automation. He spoke about how you have to make biscuits tougher nowadays for automation, because people do not pack them into bags anymore, they come off conveyor belts. So if you think the quality of your biscuits has gone down, it has. Someone talked about the pride of working in a place and seeing a quality product come off a line. I doubt whether many members opposite would understand these things.

One of the salient points out of the closure of this factory is the need to have a good industry policy. This government has no industry policy, and I saw nothing in the budget to say that there will be any industry policy. It also demonstrates the absolute necessity of having a strong union present on the site. I want to congratulate the LHMU and Leigh Hubbard from the Trades Hall Council for their fight for the workers. If it were not for them, redundancy packages would not be going to these 600 people, particularly the 180 casuals on the site, who will now get redundancy packages. Some of these casuals had 10 years service at the plant. Prior to the union coming in and negotiating these packages, they were going to be left with nothing. I despair at yet another callous multinational showing its complete disregard for its work force, which helped make the company so attractive a proposition to buy in the first place. I say to Arnott's: jam your Tim Tam. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: North Queensland: Cane Grub and Black Sigatoka Outbreaks

talk.start.para: —It is rather intriguing the way the previous speaker, the member for Chisholm, was going on: she belongs to a party whose official policy is free trade. If you want free trade, you have to accept the closure of the Arnott's factory—there is no in between here. It is regrettable that so many people in this House have those policies.

speech.para: I stand up today to raise two very depressing developments in Far North Queensland. One is the outbreak of cane grub. It seems that we are an ill-starred area over recent years. The cane grub has been a constant problem in the cane industry right from its inception in Far North Queensland. The Lacaze family recently came with many other people in a delegation to see me and they said that, in days past, when the cane grub simply got out of hand, you closed down your farm, you did something else with it for a few years and then you went back into cane again. In days past we were allowed to use effective pesticides to eradicate some of these pests. There are no recorded problems coming from the use of those pesticides over a long period of time. Maybe there are good arguments why we should not use benzine hexachloride—gamaxine is, I think, the technical name for it. It most certainly was a very effective combatant against the cane grub. For those people who say that this is nature: well, it is an indigenous insect, but its prolific numbers in the cane industry are not, of course, natural in the Australian landscape.

Recently, I flew over the northern cane fields on a very clear day—which is rare, of course, in the super wet belt—and it seemed to me that at least five per cent of the cane was down as a result of the cane grub. This is very early days yet in the season. So people are talking about projected losses of 20 per cent and it does really seem that the losses will be in that sort of order. We may be talking of losses of as much as $100 million. If we are not allowed for a year to use an effective pesticide such as the one that I have referred to to break the exponential explosion of numbers of the cane grub and we are forced to use suSCon and Confidor, we will need a massive amount to cover the huge areas if we want in any way to effectively halt the exponential rate of growth of the grub. Two-thirds of that cost will need to come from government, because the cane industry is reeling under treble impositions upon it over the last three years: record low productivity; record low CCS levels—sugar levels—in the cane; and record low prices. We have had that treble for three years. The cane industry is not in a position to be able to afford the cost of these combatants.

In addition, the black sigatoka outbreak has now taken a very serious turn in North Queensland. People are talking about our inability to eradicate it, and this opens the way for the importation of bananas into Australia. A case can now be mounted that we have black sigatoka here. We would reject that out of hand, of course. But that, plus the enormous cost burden upon the industry of black sigatoka suddenly coming into Australia, indicates clearly the absolute necessity for government to have the same approach as the Americans and every other government in the world, which is some form of protection insurance. The American Congress, as reported in the media, agreed to a $15,000 million package for crop insurance—whether these reports were true or not I have not been able to establish at this point of time, but because it was so prolific throughout the media I assume that it was true. So every other country provides crop insurance. There is a very good reason for this: people will not own up to having black sigatoka because they are frightened that, if they do, they will lose their crop, they will be bankrupted and they will lose everything—as was the case with the papaya fruit fly in North Queensland. If we get a foot-and-mouth disease outbreak, people will also be reluctant to come forward. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Long Term Operating Plan

talk.start.para: —I want to put on record the latest answer I got to question No. 2307 from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services this afternoon, trying to tell me that the long-term operating plan for Sydney airport has been substantially implemented. I just want to let the House know that we are only supposed to be getting 17 per cent movements to the north and the average figure over the last three years has been in the order of 27.3 per cent, which is 60 per cent more aircraft movements than we are supposed to be getting in Lowe. On top of that, there were breaches on eight occasions of the cap of 80 movements per hour at Sydney airport in March, and I am absolutely outraged that there is nothing in the budget to do anything to implement the long-term operating plan to provide the appropriate funding for Airservices Australia to meet the commitments that the government has promised for the people of Lowe—indeed, the people of Sydney.

—In the moments remaining, I wish to add my words to the condolence motion on the recent sad loss from our ranks of the honourable member for Aston, Peter Nugent, who died suddenly in Melbourne on 24 April. His death touched many people who had the privilege of sharing part of his life's journey. It was a measure of the contribution that Peter had made to public life that his long service earned the collective praises of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the Human Rights Subcommittee and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, as well as from both sides of politics. He was a campaigner and a crusader on humanitarian issues and had, over his years in parliament, carved out a philosophical position as a defender of the disadvantaged and a conscience on issues such as reconciliation and racism.

speech.para: Many of us choose to enter public office because we believe it to be a higher calling and that we will be able to make a positive difference for the betterment of our community and our nation. Peter Nugent's life was a classic example—for he did make a difference. At his funeral many in his electorate spoke to me of his genuine concern for them, and they had respect and warmth towards him. Peter will be sadly missed by his family, his friends, as well as by his electorate and by the parliament. I add my thoughts and prayers for his wife, Carol, and his family in supporting the motion.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —I would like to inform the House that on 11 May this year, the telecommunications company Vectus informed 138 working families in Bendigo that their jobs had disappeared. They have lost a contract with another telecommunications company called One.Tel, which has opted out of its contract and, as a result, 138 jobs have been lost in Bendigo. Of course, Bendigo has got a very high level of unemployment.

speech.para: What I find most disturbing is that coalition opposition MPs in the state of Victoria are trying to blame this on the Bracks Labor government, which is ridiculous. In fact, the same MPs have got considerable form in this very area. Jeff Kennett, the then Premier of Victoria, promised 400 call centre jobs in Bendigo, two weeks out from the previous federal election. He made a big fanfare of it; the then Liberal candidate was saying that it was a wonderful boost to the city and that this was what we could expect under a Liberal government. In fact, it is in this same area that 138 jobs have been lost. These Liberal and National Party MPs have been disgracefully trying to blame the Bracks state government when nothing could be further from the truth.

I have written to One.Tel, asking them why they have taken that decision, but there has been no reply. I suspect that I am not going to get a reply, which I find unacceptable and unAustralian. You cannot just wipe out 138 jobs in Bendigo without providing a reason for doing so, yet that is what the company has done. I will be pressuring them to find out precisely what happened and what has caused this considerable loss of jobs.

On another matter, I would like to welcome the funding announcement in last night's budget for the Calder Highway. The Calder Highway is a major highway which runs right through my electorate of Bendigo. The current Liberal government has been reneging on its commitment to fund that highway over the last two years. I have been waging a pretty substantial campaign on that matter, and I am glad to be able to say that $25 million has been allocated to the Carlsruhe bypass section, which will further enhance timeliness in getting from Melbourne to Bendigo. But I have to point out that this government had to be dragged kicking and screaming all the way to this decision.

I have raised the issue in this parliament on 11 or 12 occasions and in countless media statements over the past 18 months. But now we are seeing some movement. After all, it was this government that declared the Calder to be a road of national importance, but I had to keep reminding the government of that fact. In fact, they claimed that it was a state arterial road, but we took a photo of a sign next to the Calder which stated that it was a road of national importance. It was the former transport minister, Mr Sharp, who declared it as such in 1997. I am happy to say that the funding has now been allocated for this section. That leaves two more sections to be dealt with before the project is completed. I urge the government to give us a completion date. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak about the wonderful win last night for older Australians and self-funded retirees. In the Petrie electorate, there are 13,000 older Australians aged over 65. What is most welcome is the $300 payment to people of age pension age who receive income support. I refer also to the extension of the telephone allowance, amounting to $17.50 a quarter, for those who do not get a Commonwealth seniors health care card. The move to increase the income limit on the Commonwealth seniors health care card to $50,000 for singles and $80,000 for couples, and $50,000 each for couples separated by illness or respite, will be widely welcomed in my electorate as well.

speech.para: Another good initiative is the negotiation that will be undertaken with state and territory governments to extend to those health care card holders some or all of the territory and state concessions. I refer also to the exempting of superannuation assets from the pension and allowances means test for people over the age of 55 but under pension age, and the increase in the low income aged saving rebate and pensioners rebates to up to $2,230 for individuals and $1,602 for each member of a couple. These moves are very welcome for those in my electorate, where there are many self-funded retirees. The incomes of many of those self-funded retirees are very close to the pension rate, and they have suffered for many years, trying to accommodate for increases in living costs. So these moves are very welcome.

Another huge initiative announced last night was the increase in the Medicare levy threshold to $20,000 for single seniors. That is absolutely fantastic. The Treasurer is to be commended for that particular move. I also welcome the increase in aged care funding. It has increased by 77 per cent since 1995-96. We are an ageing population. More and more Australians want the option to stay at home. Many of those packages will include community care packages and will help in the provision of aged care services in the community.

On a very positive note, I end with reference to the imputation credits and the abolition of stamp duty, which will affect some five million Australians who own shares. Stamp duty on most share transactions will be abolished, which is worth some $675 million, and excess imputation credits will be refunded to resident individuals, complying superannuation funds, charities and gift deductible organisations. Shareholders will also receive the benefit of capital gains tax concessions when funds distribute eligible capital gains. All in all, the budget has some wonderful initiatives for pensioners, self-funded retirees and shareholders. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The member for Petrie mentioned home and community care, so I hope she listens when I mention the concerns raised in a letter I received from one of my constituents. It is time that people in the community who bear responsibility for caring for aged relatives get the support they need and deserve—and it ain't there in the fine print of the budget. I received a letter recently from Slawka Gawlik, who lives in my electorate of Port Adelaide in the suburb of Largs Bay. She described the difficulties she faced caring for her aged mother at home and expressed her exasperation upon finding that the government's aged care package failed her when she needed it most. The letter is also a plea for governments to provide a realistic level of financial assistance and more flexible respite care provisions to enable proper in-home care of aged people.

speech.para: I have raised in this House on earlier occasions instances where aged people and their families have been put under immense pressure by the failure of the government to provide sufficient nursing home beds. I have also pointed out that this failure puts extra pressure on our already overloaded public hospitals. Slawka's letter identifies yet another area in which the government has failed the community. Slawka's mother was in receipt of a low level care aged care package for three years, until January 2000 when her health worsened and she moved into Slawka's family home. Slawka left full-time work to care for her mother. During 2000, the cost of the aged care package rose to $4 an hour and she found it increasingly difficult to make ends meet while living on the pension and continuing to pay for health insurance, household bills and living expenses. She was also paying about $100 per month for incontinence pants—something many elderly people need and for which assistance was unavailable.

Earlier this year, Slawka's mother was assessed as a high level care patient, and Slawka was strongly advised to seek respite to avoid physical and mental burnout. However, as her mother has always feared being placed in an institution, she thought it necessary to break into her respite gradually. Slawka therefore sought respite for weekends only, but found she had to book a minimum of one or two weeks. This highlights the need for more flexibility in the provision of that care.

Slawka's mother then suffered a heart attack and, after leaving hospital, was placed in the hospital in the home program, but her health deteriorated so badly that a decision was made to seek palliative care. Slawka contacted St Anna's Hostel, from which her mother was receiving an aged care package, to advise them of her mother's worsening conditions, but was told that they had a `no lift policy' and that they would be unable to continue with the aged care package. So around she went in circles. In her letter, Slawka writes:

quote.para: How ridiculous, that when we are most in need it seems that the program can't help. Mum had come to the stage where she needed two people to help shower and move her. We are aware that there weren't any vacant beds in nursing homes, but now the aged care package couldn't help.

speech.para: She says more, but I could perhaps refer to the other issues Slawka has raised in another speech. However, in the fine print of the budget last night I could not find anything that will help Slawka's mother, or people in her situation. (Time expired)

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr NELSON
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —Firstly, last night's budget announced a range of measures, including: a growth forecast of 3.25 per cent for the next financial year, a current account deficit of three per cent of GDP, and inflation forecast to fall again to below two per cent for the coming year. Those are in the context of a forecast surplus of $1.5 billion for the next financial year. Underneath those things was a range of extremely important measures—in particular, those targeted at senior Australians and self-funded retirees. Members of the Australian community who elect members of parliament and send them to Canberra at times have reason to wonder what they do in Canberra. But older Australians in particular should be aware that, in no small part, these measures have been delivered because of the diligent and constructive hard work and advocacy put in by the member for Robertson on behalf of his constituents, particularly those over the age of 65.

speech.para: My colleagues and I are facing an election this year and, as I travel from one end of the country to the other as the parliamentary secretary for defence, I cannot help but be impressed—if not in some cases disturbed—by the differences that there are amongst Australians. The further you go from the Opera House, the more Australians are concerned that they are perhaps living in not just another part of Australia but indeed another country. My constituents write to me, for example, concerned that we have only one television set for every 50 illegal detainees. But when I go to remote parts of Australia people suggest that we sort the Collins class submarines out by getting them out there to sink a couple of boats. Such is the extreme variation in the views that are held.

As we cross the threshold from the 20th to the 21st century, I say to my constituents that, as the member for Bradfield, I will do everything I can to see that we become a country that values the health and integrity of human life as much as one which achieves its economic objectives. In all the things I do, I see barriers to the creation of wealth as being the enemy of equitable social policy. I will strive to see that Australia is a country that nurtures the idealism of young people and that all Australians, irrespective of where they live, understand that their views will be solicited and heard, and that all Australians will be cared for—but that, in return, we expect those who derive a benefit from our society to give something back in return.

Finally, for my own children and the young generation in the electorate of Bradfield, my aspiration is that we be seen as an outward looking, competitive and compassionate country; that we are reconciled with our indigenous history; and that we are imbued with the values of hard work, self-sacrifice and tolerance. Everything I do on behalf of the people of Bradfield can be measured against that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Like the honourable member for Port Adelaide, I wish to read a letter that I received about the safety net not catching elderly Australians. The letter says:

quote.para: Dear Harry

Whilst you were in Melbourne celebrating the centenary of Federation my wife and self were in the Island State Credit Union Heritage Branch endeavouring to collect our pension. This was due from Centrelink on May 10 2001.

Running our cards through the auto balance, we found that our entitlement had not been credited to our accounts. We were told that Centrelink had not processed the payments, and that this was the case with all the welfare recipients served by that branch. As luck would have it, we had sufficient in our S7 accounts to enable us to draw on that. But we should have liked you to have seen the large number of pensioners who were there waiting without funds. Most appeared to be stony broke, and also depending on what was their due. One poor old chap, who was eighty-plus, just sat on the bench looking at his balance in utter dismay. He looked sick, and was poorly dressed in an old hand-me-down suit that probably came from Vinnies or the Salvos op-shop. We were told that the pensions would be available later in the day, possibly after lunchtime. This sad debacle meant that all welfare recipients there today were being treated as second class citizens by whoever was responsible. What with all the ballyhoo about Federation etc here was one old guy with the arse out of his pants wondering where his lunch was coming from. Hobart was wet and freezing cold, what was he supposed to do, walk around in the rain until the powers that be processed his entitlement.

The Federal Liberal Government has repeatedly shown its lack of compassion and contempt of older Australians. John Howard repeatedly promulgates his priorities towards self serving policies that denigrate the senior citizens of Australia. Taxing charities (who provide hand-outs to the poor) is a classic example of his ineptitude in this regard. Pensioners today are even more dependent on getting their payments on time, what with the GST to fork out every time they turn around. Whilst we had a thermos of coffee in our old car, most of the others there had neither that or the Vegemite Sandwich which we brought along for lunch. We have spoken to you on one occasion in the heritage branch of the ISCU and know that you are a caring individual who looks out for the less fortunate. But as you were not there to see this degradation for yourself, we felt it behoved us to keep you informed.

speech.para: He says that perhaps I could pass this letter on or read it in the House. This another example of people falling through the net and, despite what the government did last night in its budget, I can assure people in the House that thousands and thousands of Australians are falling through the net, for a variety of reasons. The budget that was presented last night will not go any way at all to addressing that. (Time expired)

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —Today in the parliament I wish to raise an issue of concern to the residents of Buderim on the Sunshine Coast—that is, the difficulty we are having with increasing aircraft noise with respect to the Sunshine Coast airport. As a result of the representations I have received from numerous constituents, I have called a public meeting at Buderim at 6.15 next Wednesday, 30 May. I believe it is particularly important for people to recognise that Buderim residents are absolutely entitled to not be subjected to the increasing levels of aircraft noise which are occurring as a result of changes in flight patterns. I have received a letter from Mr Julian Chester, who pointed out to me that there has been a significant increase in the noise generated by aircraft flying directly over Buderim. This is having a detrimental effect on residents and the enjoyment of their lifestyle. This has been caused by changes to flight paths for commuter aircraft using the Sunshine Coast airport.

speech.para: It is unacceptable that a residential area such as Buderim should be disadvantaged in this way. Consequently, I have spoken personally with the Deputy Prime Minister to point out my concerns and outrage at the way in which residents and constituents of mine are being treated with contempt with regard to the increasing levels of aircraft noise. Mrs Marilyn Keelty has organised a petition of Buderim residents. So far, more than 500 people—and I would expect the number to grow—have signed this petition expressing their concern over the fact that the peaceful enjoyment of their life is being interrupted by the changes in these flight patterns. I have also contacted the department to ensure that bureaucrats will attend the public meeting. They will be held to account by the local community for the outrageous changes which are occurring and which are now reducing the quality of life for people living at Buderim.

The Department of Transport and Regional Services has a lot to answer for. These changes in flight patterns are totally unacceptable, they are totally outrageous, and they are totally rejected by the local community. As the local member, I am determined to make sure that we reverse the situation so that the lifestyle of people at Buderim can be restored. I place on record my very strong concern about what is happening at Buderim. It is unacceptable and it must be changed. It must be reversed. These bureaucrats will be held to account at the public meeting next Wednesday.

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)—In accordance with standing order 275A, the time for members statements has concluded.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 28 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) With respect to the decision to select the Gosport Corridor as the preferred by-pass for Moree, NSW, what was the cost of the alternative Bolla Bolla outer by-pass option, and did this include the cost of rail overbridges.

(2) Was any consideration given to, and costings prepared for, a Bolla Bolla by-pass option that used an alternative to rail overbridges, eg level crossings; if so, what was the cost of the modified option.

(3) What will be the maximum speed allowable for vehicles travelling on the proposed new Gosport Street route and how many sets of traffic lights, pedestrian crossings and roundabouts will be included on the route.
(4) How do the statistics referred to in part (3) compare with the (a) current route through Balo Street and (b) alternative Bolla Bolla option.

(5) Did consultation occur with individual residents and businesspeople along the proposed Gosport Street route; if so, (a) what organisation conducted that consultation, (b) how many meetings were held, (c) how many people attended each meeting and (d) what was the outcome of the meetings.
(6) Has an environmental impact study for the Gosport Street corridor been completed; if so, is it available to the public.

(7) Was the support of the Moree Plains Shire Council and the Chamber of Commerce for the Gosport route conveyed to the Government in writing; if so, are copies of those letters available to the public.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The estimated cost of the alternative Bolla Bolla option is $54m. This included provision for two railway overbridges and one level crossing.

(2) Yes. The estimated cost of the Bolla Bolla option with level crossings rather than rail overbridges was reported in Appendix 7 of the Preferred Route Corridor Selection Report as $36m. However, in consideration of this option the NSW Rail Access Corporation (RAC) advised the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority (RTA) that its policy is not to allow any new level crossings. Accordingly, RAC indicated that it will not agree to the installation of level crossings over the Narrabri to Moree or Moree to Camurra (Weemelah/North Star) lines.

(3) The posted speed limit to be adopted on various sections of the Gosport Street route has not yet been finalised. North of the Mehi River it is likely to include an 80 km/h zone and possibly a 100 km/h zone. South of the Mehi River it is likely to be set at a level appropriate to the urban environment and this is likely to be between 50 km/h and 70 km/h). The RTA will consult with Moree Plains Shire Council before any decisions are made.

The initial concept design for the Gosport Street route includes one set of traffic lights, at the intersection of Gosport and Alice Streets. No marked pedestrian crossings and no roundabouts are included in the concept design.
(4) (a) and (b)

Moree Plains Shire Council has adopted a 50 km/h speed zone for the urban area of Moree. The existing Newell Highway route along Balo Street has one set of traffic lights, four marked pedestrian crossings and two roundabouts.

The alternative Bolla Bolla option would have no sets of traffic lights, and no pedestrian crossings. However, it would include a major 4-way intersection with the Gwydir Highway. A concept design for this intersection has not been developed since the route was not selected as the preferred corridor.

Prior to selection of the Gosport Street route as the preferred corridor, consultation with individual residents and businesspeople along the proposed Gosport Street route did not take place on a one-on-one basis.
However, Egis Consulting Australia Pty Ltd on behalf of the RTA undertook an extensive community involvement program. The program included:

answer.para: · community interest group meetings;
· public displays;
· community newsletters;
· community response sheets;
· the formation of a Community Consultative Committee;
· two Value Management workshops; and
· the provision of a free telephone information line

quote.para: Full details of the program are documented in Section 3 of the Preferred Route Corridor Selection Report.
(6) No. The RTA is currently preparing an Environmental Impact Statement for the proposed Gosport Street route, which is expected to be ready for public display by mid 2001.

(7) Both Moree Plains Shire Council and the Chamber of Commerce were involved in public consultations and conveyed their written support for the Gosport Street option to the RTA and its consultants during the route selection process. Their views and activities are reported in Section 6 of the Preferred Route Corridor Selection Report.
The Commonwealth also received various representations from Moree Plains Shire Council, the Chamber of Commerce and other stakeholders during the consultative process leading to route selection.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 December 2000:

quote.para: (1) In his answer to question No.1644 (Hansard, 16 August 2000, page 19216) did he state that the Calder Highway is a State arterial road and therefore the responsibility of the Victorian Government.

(2) Now that the Prime Minister has announced funding of $1.6 billion for regional, suburban and country roads, will he (a) concede that the Calder Highway is a Road of National Importance and (b) allocate funds from the Roads to Recovery program to continue the duplication of the highway.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes, in terms of defining which level of government is responsible for which road, the Calder Highway is a State arterial road and therefore the responsibility of the Victorian Government. The Roads of National Importance Program is a Federal Government funded Program designed to assist with the upgrading of nationally important roads.
(2) (a) The Federal Government initially offered to declare the Calder Highway a Road of National Importance in November 1996. The highway has since remained a Road of National Importance.
(b) Funds from the Roads to Recovery Program are directed to local councils to fund local roads, in accordance with council priorities.
Although the Calder Highway is a declared Road of National Importance, funding of projects is dependent on budgetary priorities.
Funding for continued duplication of the Calder Highway will therefore be considered by the Federal Government in the context of preparing the 2001-02 Budget.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Who recommended the need to appoint a wine consultant for Kirribilli House.
(2) How was the consultant selected.
(3) Who is the consultant.
(4) How many hours has the consultant devoted to the selection of wines, and what is the basis of his or her payment.
(5) From whom were the selected wines purchased.
(6) Is he able to say whether the consultant holds any shares or has an interest in the selected liquor companies or wineries.
(7) What wines were selected for Kirribilli House or The Lodge as a result of the use of a consultant, and what was the purchase price for each of the wines selected.
(8) In selecting the wines, what guidelines were put in place as to the needs of the occupants of Kirribilli House and The Lodge.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: In relation to (1) to (7) I am advised by my department that:

(1), (2) and (3) My department initiated the process for the engagement of a consultant to provide advice regarding the establishment of a wine cellar and the selection of wines for use at the official residences. A select tender process was undertaken. Five organisations with a recognised profile in the industry were invited to respond. Mr Peter Bourne was the successful tenderer.

(4) Under the terms and conditions of the consultancy, the level of remuneration is based on the delivery of a range of agreed outcomes. A fee of $8,000 has been paid for developing the initial purchasing strategy and cellar plan. A further $7,200 is payable over three years for a tri-annual cellar assessment ($800 x 9) and subsequent advice on wine selection.
(5) Selected wines were purchased from many wineries from all states except Queensland.

(6) Mr Bourne is an independent consultant who has advised that he does not have a financial interest in any winery or retail wine outlet. Under the terms and conditions of the consultancy contract, Mr Bourne has warranted that no conflict of interest exists, or is likely to arise, in the performance of the service.
(7) A total of 58 dozen bottles has been recommended by Mr Bourne and subsequently purchased by the department for cellaring and future use. The average cost of the wine was $24.75 per bottle.

(8) No specific instructions were provided by me. However a specification of requirements was developed by my department for the consultancy service. This included a requirement that the wines served at the official residences be Australian and represent a diversity of growing regions. The consultancy service required the development and implementation of a strategy/cellar plan to ensure an appropriate standard of Australian wine was always available for use at the official residences. The strategy supports the showcasing of Australian wines both in the short and long terms.
The strategy/cellar plan addressed:

answer.para: · a purchasing strategy to meet short, medium and long term requirements at the residences;
· recommendations of particular wines to be purchased for a range of functions;
· suggested sources for purchasing the wine; and
· suggested wine storage locations to meet the department's requirements.

quote.para: The decision to establish a quality wine cellar to showcase Australian wines, an industry which earns nearly $1.5 billion in exports per annum, has been commended by the Winemakers' Federation of Australia Inc., who wrote in the following terms:

“May I also take this opportunity to commend you on your interest in developing a quality wine cellar to showcase the range of Australian wine brands, appropriately representing the diversity and character of Australia's wine producing regions. No doubt, the expert advice you received from Peter Bourne will add substantial value to the quality image of Australian wine and `Brand Australia' when the wine is presented to visiting dignitaries and Heads of State.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) On what basis was the draft master plan for Coolangatta Airport rejected because the Tweed Shire Council had not agreed to extend the runway into NSW land.
(2) Have other master plans been rejected because of opposition from local councils.

(3) Given the importance of Coolangatta Airport to the Gold Coast, did the useful advice referred to in his Media Release of 1 December 2000 from the Member for McPherson and the Gold Coast business community recommend extension of the airport.

(4) Will his Department assist the operators of the Coolangatta Airport in preparing a runway extension confined within the airport site and will he then approve the draft master plan as stated in his Media Release of 1 December 2000, irrespective of the views of Tweed Shire Council.
(5) When
(a) was Coolangatta Airport built on the current site
(b) did the Tweed Shire Council zone the land in question as crown land
(c) did the local council give approval for residential development right up to the edge of the Crown land.

(6) Has any Member of the House of Representatives or Senate made representations to him, his office, or his Department, either written or oral against the extension of the runway, be it within or beyond existing airport boundaries.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The draft master plan presented a planning concept (ie extension of the main runway) of Coolangatta Airport which not only physically extended beyond the airport boundary but also into land which the custodian and planning authority - Tweed Shire Council- is unwilling to protect for airport purposes. This created a situation where the airport master plan might be simply unachievable. In view of this I did not regard the draft master plan as a feasible land use planning tool.

(2) No, but the Airports Act 1996 is designed to encourage planning dialogue between airports and the local authorities around them, and their input has been an important ingredient to a number of master plans.
(3) The information in question referred to the impact on the local economy of the airport generally and of the proposal to extend the runway at an unspecified time in the future.

(4) I have advised Coolangatta Airport that I would be prepared to approve a runway extension if it was confined within the airport site. The Airport has until 30 May 2001 to submit a revised Fresh Draft Master Plan.

(5) (a) According to Gold Coast Airport Pty Ltd (the lessee of Coolangatta Airport), there has been a landing strip at Coolangatta since 1936. Regular Public Transport began to be catered for in 1939.

(b) Tweed Shire Council has never “zoned” the land as crown land. It is crown land because it belongs to the State of New South Wales. Tweed Shire Council has power to make zoning decisions in relation to the land.
(c) That information is not available to the Commonwealth.
(6) Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) With respect to the charging arrangements for the provision of air traffic services, has his attention been drawn to a practice whereby some pilots provide an incorrect aircraft call-sign in order to avoid being billed for landing at general aviation airports.
(2) What is the penalty for such an act.
(3) Have any prosecutions occurred for such acts since 1995; if so, how many in each year.
(4) Are there safety consequences of this behaviour.
(5) Has Airservices Australia, his Department or the Civil Aviation Safety Authority issued any information warning of the risks and implications of such practices.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am aware that there has been concern that, in the absence of an air traffic control service, some general aviation pilots may not follow correct procedures with regard to Mandatory Broadcast Zone (MBZ) requirements, as they are obliged to do in order to ensure that other traffic is aware of their position and intentions.

With regard to the alleged use of incorrect callsigns by general aviation pilots, I am advised by Airservices Australia that this does not appear to be an issue at controlled aerodromes with respect to Airservices' navigation charges. Rather it would seem to be one of evasion of legitimate charges being levied by the airport operator.
Additionally, I am advised by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) that:
(2) The Civil Aviation Act, Regulations and Orders do not provide for an offence for this type of conduct.

(3) To date, consistent with its lack of powers in this respect, CASA has not investigated or taken prosecution action against any pilot for providing an incorrect aircraft callsign in order to avoid being billed for landing at general aviation airports.
(4) CASA believes the safety consequences of this behaviour to be limited.

(5) CASA, as the relevant agency, has not undertaken any specific safety education targeting behaviour of this kind. However CASA advises that publications such as the Visual Flight Guide regularly contain information reminding pilots of correct radio procedures.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson

subdebateinfo.title: Family Court of Western Australia: Mr Peter Brewer
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2291)

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a court order issued in Perth in December 1997 giving Mr Peter Brewer rights of access to his daughter, Zoe Brewer.

(2) Has it been brought to his attention that on 21 April 1998 Mr Brewer's ex-wife and her partner Jose Resina left Australia with Zoe Brewer, and that this act has been determined by the Family Court of Western Australia to be in defiance of its court order granting Mr Brewer rights of access to his daughter.
(3) Is it the case that Mr Resina illegally left Australia in 1999, thereby forfeiting a recognisance of $20,000 which was being held by the court.

(4) Is there any mechanism available to the Commonwealth Government whereby this forfeited recognisance money could be made available to Mr Brewer to enable him to pursue his legal battle to have his daughter returned to Australia.

(5) In a letter to Mr Brewer, dated 15 January 1999, did the Australian Federal Police (AFP) undertake to investigate the possibility of extraditing Mr Resina and tell Mr Brewer the Crown Solicitor's attempts in this regard would be monitored; if so, have there been any outcomes from the investigations; if so what are those outcomes.
(6) What assistance has his Department provided to Mr Brewer following the promise of help in a letter from him dated 25 January 2000.
(7) Is there any other form of assistance that his Department, or any other Commonwealth Government agency, can offer Mr Brewer in his attempt to have the Family Court's determination enforced.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes, I have been fully briefed by my Department on the court order issued in Perth in December 1997, which gave Mr Brewer rights of access to his daughter Zoe Brewer, and more broadly, on the circumstances surrounding Mr Brewer's proceedings under the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (“the Convention”).
The order made in the Family Court of Western Australia on 17 December 1997 formed part of Mr Brewer's application for access made on 29 April 1999 under the Convention.

That access application was translated into French and transmitted by my Department to the French Central Authority on 1 June 1999. Mr Brewer made the application following the rejection on 12 April 1999 by the French Central Authority of his application for the return of Zoe to Australia under Article 27 of the Convention.

On 6 April 2000 a provisional order for access was made in the French Regional Court of Grasse. This order was made in similar terms to the 17 December 1997 order but takes into account the child's current French residency status and provides for the contact sought by Mr Brewer in his application for access. The mother subsequently appealed this decision and, to date, the appeal application has not been heard.

(2) Yes, I am informed that Mr Brewer's ex partner and her partner Jose Resina left Australia with Zoe Brewer on 21 April 1998 after Orders made in the Family Court of Western Australia on 17 December 1997 prohibited Zoe from leaving Australia.

As the child was born outside of marriage, Western Australian law, not Commonwealth law, determined the parents' respective rights and obligations in relation to the child. At the time of the removal, the Family Court Act 1975 (WA) provided that a mother of an ex nuptial child had full custodial and guardianship rights in relation to that child and an unmarried father had no statutory rights of custody of his child.
Therefore, at the time of the removal, Mr Brewer did not have rights of custody under Western Australian law and, as a result, had no rights of custody under the Convention.

Nevertheless, the Family Court of Western Australia made a Declaration on 12 August 1998, in accordance with Article 15 of the Convention, that the removal of the child from Australia was wrongful. That decision was not binding on a French Court or the French Central Authority. It was the opinion of the French Central Authority that Mr Brewer's application for the return did not fulfil the “rights of custody” requirements of the Convention. Article 27 of the Convention provides that a Central Authority or Contracting State is not bound to accept an application if it considers the requirements of the Convention are not fulfilled or that the application is otherwise not well founded.

Mr Brewer's lack of “rights of custody” under the Convention was the basis of the refusal by the French Central Authority to accept Mr Brewer's application for the return of his child. I note that unmarried Western Australian fathers were given parental responsibility by virtue of amendments contained in the Family Court Act 1997 (WA) which commenced on 26 September 1998.

(3) I have been advised by the Western Australian Crown Solicitor's Office that to answer the question would offend s.243 of the Family Court Act 1997 (WA). It would therefore be inappropriate for me to comment.

(4) The possibility of releasing any money held by the Family Court of Western Australia, which is a state court, is a matter for that Court or for the Western Australian Attorney-General to determine.
(5) I am advised that the AFP can find no reference to a letter dated on 15 January 1999. There is, however, correspondence dated 15 October 1999.

In the letter dated 15 October 1999, the AFP advised Mr Brewer that Commonwealth offences committed in this case were incidental to core State charges and would probably not be considered as extraditable offences in isolation.

The Crown Solicitor in Western Australia was identified as the primary agent with responsibility for any extradition requests. The Crown Solicitor has since advised the AFP that the extradition request was not approved by the Western Australian Police Commissioner.
I am advised that the AFP gave no undertaking to advise Mr Brewer of the results of the extradition request and that Mr Brewer was also in contact with the Crown Solicitor at the time.

(6) As outlined in question 1, my Department assisted Mr Brewer to seek enforcement of his access rights under the Convention after he made an application for access under the Convention to France. A French provisional order for access, in similar terms to those sought in Mr Brewer's application, was obtained on 6 April 2000. With the making of that order, the French Central Authority's power to act under the Convention and the involvement of the Australian Commonwealth Central Authority ceased.
The mother has now appealed that decision, as she is entitled to do under French law. That appeal is a private family law matter between the parties.

I am advised that financial assistance is available in France for such proceedings. My Department has advised Mr Brewer that such assistance is available, but to the knowledge of my Department, he has not yet completed the forms required by the French authorities to determine his eligibility for assistance.

(7) As I have explained, the declaration of the Family Court of Western Australia that the removal of Zoe from Australia was wrongful was not legally binding in France. The French Central Authority's refusal to accept Mr Brewer's application for Zoe' s return to Australia was permitted by the terms of the Convention. There is, therefore, nothing further the Australian Government can do to assist him to have Zoe returned to Australia. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has been consulted in relation to the Brewer matter generally and has confirmed that this matter is for Mr Brewer to pursue privately through the French legal system.

Following the French Central Authority's refusal to accept the return application, France became the appropriate jurisdiction to determine issues relating to residence and contact arrangements for Zoe. The French Court made orders for contact. The mother appealed against those orders. The appeal has not yet been listed for hearing. As Mr Brewer retained a private lawyer for the appeal proceedings, the matter is a private family law matter between Mr Brewer and the mother. Therefore, France is now the appropriate jurisdiction to determine the outcome of the appeal relating to orders made following Mr Brewer's successful application for access.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Transport and Regional Services: Badgerys Creek
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2292)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Has his Department recently held discussions with Fairfield City Councillor Robert Cork, concerning plans to change the local zoning in the Badgerys Creek area.
(2) Did his Department tell Clr Cork during discussions that the changes to zoning would only approve buildings compatible with an airport.
(3) When were the discussions were held.
(4) Which employees of his Department spoke to Clr Cork.
(5) Has he been involved in any discussions directly with Clr Cork; if so, when were the discussions held.
(6) Were other people involved in these discussions; if so, what are the names of the people involved in these discussions.
(7) Has his Department plans to change the zoning of the Badgerys Creek area so that only buildings compatible with an airport will be approved.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) to (6) Neither I nor any members of my staff, nor relevant officers of the Department of Transport and Regional Services, can recollect any recent discussion with a person identifying himself as a Fairfield City Councillor in relation to this matter.

(7) The Government has decided to retain ownership of the Badgerys Creek site and to legislate to protect the site from incompatible development in surrounding areas. The measures required to implement this decision are currently being examined.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Long Term Operating Plan
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2307)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Will Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport (KSA) not be privatised until the noise pollution problems at the airport have been permanently resolved, consistent with the Governments Putting People First policy.
(2) Is the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) for KSA still to be fully implemented.
(3) Under the LTOP, what is the average percentage of aircraft movements to the north, west and east of the airport for the last three years, individually and in aggregate.
(4) Is the Government in receipt of advice from Airservices Australia that the LTOP for KSA is unsafe or unworkable.
(5) Do Sydney residents receive more aircraft noise now than before the LTOP was introduced.
(6) Are Sydney residents more at risk of aircraft crashes since the LTOP was introduced.
(7) Can the LTOP be fully implemented with the Government's proposed expansion of Sydney Airport and Bankstown Airport; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Government has decided, following consideration of the scoping study report into the sale of the Airport, to sell Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport by a 100% trade sale to be completed in the second half of this year.

(2) The Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) has been substantially implemented with the exception of a small number of elements. For example, the restructuring of the arrival airspace has yet to be implemented. This includes implementation of the “trident” and “power-off” approaches.
Aggregate 27.3% (north), 8.3% (west), 12.5% (east)

(5) LTOP introduced a regime of noise sharing. The Plan introduced significant reductions in noise exposure for those areas most heavily impacted under Labor's noise concentration regime. Noise sharing, by definition, resulted in some areas receiving an increase in noise while others received a decrease. However, the areas subject to an increase receive much lower levels of noise exposure than those experienced by areas close to the Airport under Labor's “Bennelong Funnel”.

(6) Safety factors have been the overriding consideration in establishing the noise sharing regime at Sydney Airport. In establishing these arrangements under LTOP the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the Hon John Sharp MP, directed Airservices Australia to undertake formal safety analyses of the operational components of the Plan prior to their implementation. Airservices Australia advises that a safety case was undertaken for each phase of LTOP implementation.

(7) I am advised that the sale of Sydney Airport and the proposed role for Bankstown Airport as an overflow airport will not be an impediment to the implementation of the remaining elements of LTOP - see response to question (2).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: Is he aware of the increased health risks to local residents around Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and Port Botany from long term exposure to toxic emissions associated with road transport travelling to and from the airport.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: No information is available on the specific contribution to the total toxics pollutant load made by vehicles travelling to and from Sydney Airport. However, I am advised that traffic studies commissioned for the then Federal Airports Corporation indicate that the proportion of total motor vehicle activity which can be directly attributed to the Airport's operations rapidly diminishes as the distance from the Airport increases.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and Bankstown Airport: Toxic Emissions
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2310)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Can he provide air toxic emissions data and risk analysis covering specific known carcinogens and toxins, including but not restricted to (a) benzene, (b) 1-3 butadiene and (c) toluene generated by total airport operations at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport (KSA) and Bankstown Airport during 2000.

(2) Is he able to say whether Sydney Airport Corporation Limiteds (SACL) claim of insignificant health risks from exposure to emissions around Sydney airport during the Commission of Inquiry into the Precision Runway Monitoring (PRM) System north of KSA, excluded measurement of the health risk north of Sydney airport and did not assess risk from long term exposure to specific transport-emission related carcinogens such as benzene, 1-3 butadiene and toluene.

(3) Is he able to say whether, according to the NSW Cancer Council, the highest occurrence area for lung cancer in the eastern half of the Sydney basin is concentrated around Sydney Airport and Port Botany.
(4) Can he provide evidence in support of SACLs claim during the March 2000 PRM Inquiry that its two air pollution monitors recorded no significant change in air emissions since 1992.
(5) Can he verify whether SACLs finding of insignificant risk on the basis of the monitoring data used in this assessment is applicable for inner western Sydney suburbs downwind of Sydney airport.

(6) Can he provide air toxic emissions data and risk analysis covering specific known carcinogens and toxins, including (a) benzene, (b) 1-3 butadiene and (c) toluene generated by total airport operations at KSA and Bankstown Airport during 2010 to reflect the metropolitan area impacts of the publicised scenarios of (i) removing regional aircraft from KSA, (ii) increasing the numbers of jet operations at KSA and (iii) expanding Bankstown Airport.

(7) Can he quantify what lung cancer risk in the Sydney metropolitan area is attributable to toxic transport emissions, in view of the reported 53% risk factor quoted by the US Environment Protection Agency for the Minneapolis St Paul metropolitan area, and also in view of the closed-basin nature of the Sydney metropolitan area, and the relatively high level of benzene in Australian motor vehicle fuel by world standards.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am unaware of any information on the quantity of emissions of the specified pollutants generated by Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and Bankstown Airport operations for the year 2000.

(2) I am advised that evidence provided by the Sydney Airports Corporation Limited outlined the nature of the air quality monitoring arrangements on and close to Sydney Airport, listed the types of emissions assessed (which do not include benzine 1-3 butadiene and toluene) and indicated general compliance with standards for the pollutants measured.

(3) I am advised that examination of the latest available report of the NSW Cancer Council on this issue (Cancer Maps for NSW: Variation by Local Government Area 1991-1995) shows that, in the eastern half of the Sydney Basin, significantly higher than NSW average rates of lung cancer in males occur in Leichhardt, Sydney, South Sydney, Marrickville and Ashfield; for females it is in Sydney, South Sydney, Randwick, Leichhardt and Waverley. Therefore, the highest rates of lung cancer in the eastern half of the Sydney basin are not concentrated around Sydney Airport and Port Botany.

(4) Air quality on and in the vicinity of Sydney Airport has been monitored since 1992 by the airport operator. I am advised that the air quality data gathered by the operator is sent to the NSW Environment Protection Authority for validation and incorporation into its metropolitan air quality results. Reports on the air quality monitoring are public documents and copies can be made available to the Honourable Member.

(5) I am advised that the NSW Environment Protection Authority operates a network of permanent air quality monitoring stations throughout the Sydney Basin. One of these stations is located at Earlwood in the inner west. Therefore there is independent ongoing monitoring of air quality in that area.
(6) I am unaware of the existence of any specific information for the scenarios referred to in the question.

(7) A facts sheet available on the internet site of the Cancer Council of New South Wales indicates that 77% of lung cancers in women and 84% of lung cancers in men in Australia are caused by cigarette smoking. A number of other risk factors are identified. Risks attributable to toxic transport emissions, as such, are not quantified.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Transport and Regional Services: Contributions and Gifts
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2314)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Has he received any contributions or gifts from vested corporate interests in Sydney Airport Corporation and Bankstown Airport Corporation and their related ground transport infrastructure; if so, what are the details.
