talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) The details of gifts received by Ministers and their families are recorded in the Register of Members' Interests or the Register of Senators' Interests as the case may be.
The details of donations to political parties can be obtained through the Australian Electoral Commission.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Do many airports now ban aircraft that do not comply with noise levels as described in Chapter 3 of Annex 16, Volume 1 of the Convention on International Civil Aviation.

(2) Do the airports include (a) Montreal (Dorval) and Toronto (Lester B Pearson) in international airports Canada, (b)Ruzyne (Prague) Airport in the Czech Republic, (c) Copenhagen Airport Roskilde in Denmark, (d) Lappeenranta Airport in Finland, (e) Charles de Gaulle Airport in France, (f) Dresden, Dusseldorf, Frankfurt, Hamburg, Hannover-Langenhagen, Cologne-Bonn, Munich, Paderborn-Lippstadt, Schonefeld, Tegel and Tempelhof airports in Germany, (g) Alghero Airport (Milan) in Italy, (h) Luxembourg International Airport in Luxembourg, (i) Schiphol Airport in The Netherlands, (j) Oslo Gardemoen Airport in Norway, (k) Biggen Hill, Gatwick, Heathrow, Kent, London City, Southampton and Stanstead airports in the UK and (l) John Wayne-Orange County, Santa Monica, Aspen-Pitkin County/Sardy Field, Ronald Reagan National and Jackson Hole airports in the USA.
(3) Are Chapter 3 aircraft 50% quieter than the aircraft presently allowed in Sydney Airport.

(4) Will Sydney be added to the list of countries banning aircraft that do not comply with noise levels as described in Chapter 3 of Annex 16, Volume 1 of the Convention on International Civil Aviation; if so, when; if not, why not.

(5) Is he able to say whether the World Health Organization has suggested a standard guideline value for average outdoor noise levels of 55 dB(A) be applied during normal daytime in order to prevent significant interference with the normal activities of local communities; if so, how many people at any time in the Sydney area are likely to be affected by aircraft noise levels that exceed this level.

(6) Is he able to say whether the OECD, in 1986, reported thresholds for noise nuisance as being (in day-time LAeq) (a) noise exposure at 55-60 dB(A) noise creates annoyance, (b) noise exposure at 60-65 dB(A) annoyance increases considerably and (c) noise exposure above 65 dB(A) constrained behaviour patterns, symptomatic of serious damage caused by noise.
(7) How many people at any one time in the Sydney area are likely to be affected by aircraft noise levels that exceed these levels.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) passed a resolution in 1990 to phase out Chapter 2 aircraft by March 2002. The major aviation countries have introduced restrictions on Chapter 2 aircraft in response the ICAO resolution. I am pleased to say that Australia has been at the forefront of these initiatives.

I am not prepared to devote the resources that would be required to establish in detail the operational constraints applying to Chapter 2 aircraft at all the airports specified in the Honourable Member's question.

(3) and (4) The aircraft that operate into Sydney Airport are almost exclusively Chapter 3 aircraft. A very small number of Chapter 2 aircraft do operate into the Airport. In accordance with the ICAO resolution Australia has introduced Regulations banning operations by Chapter 2 aircraft by 31 March 2002.
The perceived loudness of a Chapter 3 aircraft is typically about half that of a Chapter 2 aircraft.

(5) The World Health Organization (WHO) has adopted a standard of 55 dB(A) Leq as a guideline value for preventing serious annoyance in outdoor living areas. Airservices Australia's evaluation of aircraft noise exposure patterns around Sydney Airport on the average day during the period 1 July to 30 September 2000 indicates that approximately 100,000 persons were exposed to noise exceeding 20 ANEF (this is approximately equivalent to 55 dB(A) Leq). To place this in context the New South Wales Environment Protection Authority estimates that approximately 1.5 million Sydney residents are exposed to road traffic noise levels exceeding the WHO guidelines.
(6) Yes.

(7) Airservices Australia's evaluation of aircraft noise exposure patterns around Sydney Airport on the average day during the period 1 July to 30 September 2000 indicates that approximately 100,000 persons were exposed to aircraft noise equal to or exceeding 20 ANEF (this is approximately equivalent to 55 dB(A) Leq), approximately 23,000 persons were exposed to aircraft noise equal to or exceeding 25 ANEF (this is approximately equivalent to 60 dB(A) Leq) and approximately 4,000 persons were exposed to aircraft noise equal to or exceeding 30 ANEF (this is approximately equivalent to 65 dB(A) Leq).
Residences in areas exposed to aircraft noise equal to or exceeding 30 ANEF are eligible for acoustic insulation under the Sydney Airport Noise Insulation Program.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Noise Sharing Improvements
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2318)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Did the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development issue a Media Statement T3/98 on 14 January 1998 titled Noise Sharing Improvements for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport (KSA).
(2) Does paragraph 4 of that media statement speak of an agreement reached between the Minister and Airservices Australia concerning noise-sharing improvements at KSA.
(3) What was the nature of the agreement made between Airservices Australia and the then Minister.
(4) Was the agreement in writing; if so, were any of the documents that formed the agreement generally made available to the public at the time of the making of the agreement.
(5) Is he able to say what is the source of the revised procedures as stated against the four descriptors contained in paragraph 4,of the then Minister's Media Statement T3/98.
(6) Will he provide copies of all of the documents that collectively make up the agreement; if not, why not.
(7) Will he provide a copy of any internal correspondence, including background notes, between his Department and Airservices Australia regarding this agreement.

(8) What are the current distribution arrangements for Airservices Australia background notes and if they are different today, what were the distribution arrangements for Airservices Australia background notes in 1998.
(9) For the twelve months to January 2001 on weekdays, what was the percentage of time that noise-sharing modes were used for air traffic at KSA for the full hour between 0600Hr and 0700Hr inclusive.
(10) What percentage of time that noise-sharing modes for air traffic at KSA was not possible due to weather impacts.
(11) What other factors affected the non-use of noise-sharing modes during this period.
(12) For the twelve months to January 2001 on weekdays, what was the percentage of time that noise-sharing modes were used for air traffic at KSA at 1100Hr.
(13) What percentage of time that noise-sharing modes for air traffic at KSA was not possible due to weather impacts between 1100Hr and 1500Hr inclusive.
(14) What other factors affected the non-use of noise-sharing modes during this period.
(15) For the last twelve months on the weekdays 'weather permitting', has the use of a noise-sharing mode continued to and beyond 1500 hours about 25% of the time.
(16) For the twelve months to January 2001 on weekdays, what was the percentage of time that noise-sharing modes were used for air traffic at KSA from 2000Hr till curfew.
(17) What percentage of time that noise-sharing modes for air traffic at KSA was not possible due to weather impacts during this period.
(18) What other factors affected the non-use of noise-sharing modes during this period.

(19) Are callers to the Noise Inquiry unit in relation to the operations of air traffic at KSA, when calling about the lack of the agreed change, frequently advised the reason for the failure to change to a noise-sharing mode is due traffic; if so, what are the top ten reasons for the failure to change to the noise-sharing modes at the agreed times.

(20) Is the repeated failure of Airservices Australia to achieve the agreed change to noise-sharing modes and the constant use of the excuse 'due traffic' at odds with the statement made in Media Statement T3/98 that, weather permitting, noise sharing modes based on the use of all three runways will be used irrespective of forecast traffic demand.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) to (7) I understand that the revised procedures were developed by Airservices Australia and announced by the then Minister in response to community concerns at that time about particular areas being subjected to prolonged periods of aircraft noise. There was no formal documentation of an agreement over and above the media statement of 14 January 1998 and the associated explanatory material issued as a “Backgrounder” by Airservices Australia dated 19 January 1998.

(8) It is assumed that the `background notes' referred to in the question are the `Briefing Notes' for Sydney Airport. The Briefing Notes for Sydney Airport are currently issued to members of the Sydney Airport Community Forum (SACF) and, on request, to members of the community. This task is currently carried out by the SACF secretariat based within the Department of Transport and Regional Services. The secretariat has been responsible for distributing the Briefing Notes for several years. I am advised that it carried out this function in 1998.

(9) For the period 1 January 2000 to 31 December 2000, based on times listed on the Automatic Terminal Information System (ATIS), the noise sharing modes were used for the full hour between 6am to 7am on 3.8% of the days. However it should be noted that noise sharing modes were used for at least some part of the period between 6am to 7am for 83.8% of the days.

(10) Accurate runway mode usage data that identifies weather as the sole determinant in nominating a runway is not available. Runway usage is impacted by many operational requirements and there can be multiple factors involved in nominating a runway for use, including weather conditions.

(11) Other than weather conditions, factors that affect runway selection include runway serviceability, maintenance works, obstructions on the runway, navigation aid serviceability and maintenance, lighting failures, traffic levels, traffic mix, traffic distribution and disposition, pilot requirements and the level of delay being experienced by aircraft.
(12) The use of crossing runways commenced at 1100hr for 15% of the weekdays during the period 1 January 2000 to 31 December 2000.
(13) Refer to answer to questions (10) and (11).
(14) Refer to answer to questions (10) and (11).
(15) Crossing runway use beyond 1500hrs occurred on 29.2% of the weekdays during the period 1 January 2000 to 31 December 2000.
(16) For the period 1 January 2000 to 31 December 2000 crossing runways were used for the full 3 hour period from 2000 to 2300hrs for 10.4% of the days.
(17) Refer answer to questions (10) and (11).
(18) Refer answer to questions (10) and (11).
(19) Traffic levels is one reason why a change from parallel runways to crossing runways may not be possible. Other reasons are as listed in the answer to question (11).

(20) The operational details of the noise sharing improvements announced in the Media Statement T3/98 were spelt out in a `Backgrounder' issued by Airservices Australia on 19 January 1998. Amongst other things, this document stated that `There may also be variations to the hours of the noise sharing modes if dictated by unusual traffic conditions...'

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 7 February 2001:

quote.para: What have been the dates, modes and substance of the consultations between the Federal, State and Territory Governments concerning ILO Convention No. 182, Elimination of the Worst Forms of Child Labour since the Submission Report on ILO Instruments Adopted in 1999 Convention 182 concerning the Worst Forms of Child Labour; Recommendation 190 concerning the Worst Form of Child Labour 30 November 2000 was tabled on 7 December 2000.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: I have written to all State and Territory governments seeking their assessment of the compliance of their jurisdictions' law and practice and their formal agreement to ratification of this Convention.

This matter has also been the subject of separate correspondence between the Victorian Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon Monica Gould MP and Minister Reith the former Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business which indicated Victoria's positive attitude to ratification and the process being undertaken by the Victorian Government to determine whether their law and practice is in compliance with the Convention.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) In the lease arrangements for Coolangatta Airport, are there any requirements or commitments as part of the sale arrangements relating to new developments by the new owner.
(2) Have those requirements or commitments been complied with by the Government and the new airport owner; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes, under the Sale Agreement between the Commonwealth of Australia and Gold Coast Airport Ltd (GCAL), GCAL has undertaken to spend a specified amount on aeronautical capital expenditure in the first 10 years of the lease. A proportion of this is to be spent within the first five years.

Under the Sale Agreement GCAL can obtain an extension of this time if the Commonwealth, as the lessor, is satisfied that the obligations were not fulfilled due to economic factors or force majeure events.

(2) GCAL has complied with the development obligation of the Sale Agreement to date by providing audited annual reports. Before the end of the first five year period, an assessment will need to be undertaken by the Commonwealth to ascertain whether the commitments have been met and, if not, whether the circumstances occasioning a shortfall are justifiable under the terms of the Sale Agreement.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 7 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Why is a toll being placed on the Western Sydney Orbital.
(2) What other roads classified as National Highways have tolls.
(3) Will the Western Sydney Orbital be tolled according to the length of travel on the Orbital.
(4) Can he guarantee that the toll on the Western Sydney Orbital will be capped so that a flat fee applies once a certain distance has been travelled along the Orbital?
(5) Has the Federal Government given any consideration to implementing a refund on the toll on the Western Sydney Orbital for local residents.
(6) Will he guarantee the toll will not be above $5 at the time of completion of the Orbital.
(7) Did his joint media release claim that major benefits of the Orbital include less traffic on major roads through western Sydney and less traffic on local roads.

(8) Does the environmental impact statement say that the Orbital will increase traffic on some major roads including the Horsley Drive west of Ferrers Road; if so, given that the Horsley Drive is a local road which many people in the electoral division of Prospect use on a daily basis, what considerations has he given to ensuring the Horsley Drive will carry less traffic on a daily basis after completion of the Western Sydney Orbital.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) It is important that the benefits to residents and businesses of western Sydney from the construction of the Western Sydney Orbital (WSO) be made available as soon as possible. The full $1.25 billion cost of the project is beyond the scope of the National Highway program. Without private funding (and a toll), the WSO could not be completed for at least 15 years. With the toll, the road is expected to open in 2007.
(2) No other road classified as a National Highway has a toll.

(3) and (4) Electronic tolling is proposed and although not finally decided (to be addressed in the tender process) it is likely that a toll of about 25 cents per kilometre would be charged up to a maximum of about $5 (in year 2000 dollar value)
(5) No. There are alternatives for people not wanting to pay the toll.
(6) The toll on the WSO is expected to be about $5 (in 2000 dollar values) for a car travelling the full 39km length of the WSO, but this will be determined through the tender process.

(7) The joint Ministerial media release notes that the WSO will also provide traffic relief for motorists and residents in western Sydney by removing heavy vehicle traffic from local roads, including the Cumberland Highway, the interim National Highway route through Sydney.

(8) The environmental impact statement under the heading `The Horsley Drive' (Volume 3, page 25.12) states: `Traffic volumes are increased on The Horsley Drive east of the proposal by up to 51 percent in places compared to the “do nothing” case. This is due to traffic gaining access to the proposal instead of filtering to the east through the non-motorway road network. The amount of traffic attracted to the Horsley Drive decreases further away from the proposal and is slightly reduced at Smithfield Road. Traffic volumes are also reduced between Wallgrove Road and the proposal. This is consistent with the proposal's planned function to serve as a key access to the Wetherill Park industrial zone'.
